awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Acquisition of inverse scope by L1-Mandarin L2-English learners
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning a second language can be a difficult experience for many learners, and therefore studying how second language learning works and what kinds of instructional approaches are most effective is important. This project examines the effects of different kinds of grammar instruction with Mandarin-speaking learners of English, one of the largest English learner groups in the U.S. today. The results are expected to have implications for the grammar teaching of this population in English as a Second Language classrooms, and will contribute to the understanding of language learning as well as language instruction.

This project will investigate how input/instruction affects Mandarin-speaking English second language learners' acquisition of English inverse scope, and whether learners can generalize the acquired knowledge from one structure to another. English allows inverse scope while Mandarin does not, and our preliminary findings suggest that Mandarin-speaking learners of English are not able to acquire English inverse scope based on naturalistic input alone. This project examines whether explicit instruction and/or input flooding can help learners acquire inverse scope; it further examines whether the learning effect is sustained over time. The scope interactions in two structures are examined: universal quantifier-negation scope (e.g. "Every sheep did not jump over the fence") and double-quantifier scope (e.g. "A girl stroked every kitten"). In an intervention study, learners will be instructed on one of those structures, but tested on both, to see whether they can generalize their acquired knowledge to a different but related structure. Learners will be instructed by means of either explicit rule presentation or input flooding, to determine which is the most effective. The results can contribute to both theoretical and applied research in second language acquisition.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined whether Mandarin native speakers who learn English as a second language can acquire inverse scope in English. Inverse scope is a linguistic phenomenon that exists in English but not in Mandarin. For example, a sentence that contains an indefinite ('a child') in subject position and a universal ('every book') in object position, such as "A child read every book" is ambiguous in English. On the surface-scope reading, 'a' is interpreted before 'every', and the sentence means that a specific child read all the books; on the inverse-scope reading, 'every' is interpreted before 'a', and the sentence means that every book was read by a (potentially different) child. In the corresponding sentences in Mandarin, only the surface-scope reading exists. 

Previous studies have found that English inverse scope is a challenging linguistic phenomenon to acquire for Mandarin native speakers. Therefore, the primary goal of this project was to determine how to best teach Mandarin-speaking learners of English about inverse scope in English, comparing the the efficacy of explicit instruction (teaching learners about inverse scope directly) and input flooding (artificially increasing the amount of input with the relevant structures that learners receive). The second goal was to determine whether teaching learners about inverse scope in one structure would lead to acquisition of inverse scope in a related structure as well, in order to determine whether learners are capable of linguistic generalization.

The results showed that explicit instruction was more effective than input flooding in teaching learners about inverse scope. However, learners learned only inverse scope only for the structure on which they were taught, and were not able to generalize inverse scope to a new yet related linguistic structure that also allows inverse scope. 

This study has important implications for theoretical accounts of second language acquisition because it shows that explicit instruction can improve learners' surface or explicit knowledge, but does not lead to internalized generalizations. The broader impacts of this study include an increased awareness of the kinds of challenges that Mandarin-speaking learners of English face in learning the grammar of English. Given the growing population of Mandarin-speaking students in U.S. universities, it is important to understand the particular lingustic challenges faced by this population, as well as to understand the efficacy of different instructional techniques.
